body:
From a quick look, it appears that the paths through Image.py:convert to Image.py:quantize are RGB:P, not with alpha channels. So, it falls through to the C level in Convert.c, P and PA go through the frompalette, but only P goes through topalette, and topalette looks like it only does RGB:P.  

It might work if you run quantize on the RGBA, instead of convert.

Ok further information. PA images (which are 2 channel, P + A, each 8 bits) are hard to create:
- You can't create one by adding an alpha channel to a P image. 
- Fast Octree quantization on an RGBA image returns a P image where the palette is RGBA items, not a PA image. I was getting errors trying to save that, so I'm not sure that that way is roses either. It appears that some parts of the palette code assume a max of 3 bands. 
- Internally, you can't setmode from P to PA, since that is an inplace operation. 
- There's no convert mapping from P to PA.
- Finally, I think that the only format that actually saves PA images is the internal ImageMath format, which is essentially raw data. Tiff is the only other one that reads them. 
- You can make a PA image from Image.new. 

So, PA probably isn't the answer. 

If you haven an RGBA palette, that's stored in bands (which is what the python layer uses -- the C layer seems to use interleaved palettes), then the fitst 768 bytes will be the RGB palette, and the last 256 would be the tRNS header. I'll take a look and see if that's a plausible way to handle it. And hey, it should work: PngImagePlugin.py:586. As long as info['transparency'] and encoderinfo['transparency'] are none, that should work. It's tested here: Tests/test_file_png.py:164.

Sorry, I've mistaken `PA` for a palette with RGBA entries. I've actually meant the latter â€” `P` with alpha suitable for PNG with the `tRNS` chunk.

``` python
Image.open("in.png").convert("RGBA").convert("P").save("out.png")
```

doesn't preserve the alpha either. I get the desired result with:

``` python
Image.open("in.png").convert("RGBA").quantize(method=2).save("out.png")
```

so maybe `convert("P")` could behave like `quantize(method=2)` when source is RGBA?

I think it's reasonable for RGBA converting to P to use quantize with sane defaults. I think it's also a good idea for an RGBA image to default to quantizing with FastOctree, since there's no other current option.
@wiredfool Do you have any code for this issue, assuming code is needed? I'm not sure I fully follow the discussion.
In my head. I think it's just a quick couple of bits, but that impression was from a week ago. I should have done it before it swapped out of my head.

issue.title: Conversion from RGBA -> P
issue.body:
Includes sane defaults for quantizing RGBA images.

Fixes #544

issue.title: Attached PNG loads as solid-black square
issue.body:
With this PNG file...

![logo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/46915/3022678/b1178e42-dfce-11e3-94f3-fc1395ecb7a8.png)

...this code displays a black square:

``` python
from PIL import Image
im = Image.open('logo.png')
im.show()
```

...as a result, this code which depends on Pillow also produces a black square:

``` python
from escpos import printer
usblp = printer.Usb(0x0416, 0x5011)
usblp.image("logo.png")
usblp.cut()
```

I almost filed a bug with python-escpos because Pillow failed silently rather than either working or raising an exception.
